column1: Bacteria (/bækˈtɪəriə/; sg.: bacterium) are ubiquitous, mostly free-living organisms often consisting of one biological cell.
column2: Bacteria ko (/bækˈtɪəriə/; sg.: bacterium) do, often miat́ ge biological Jivt́okoaann (Cell), ubiquitous„ sangepaa do free-living Organism ko.

column1: They constitute a large domain of prokaryotic microorganisms.
column2: Enko Prokaryotic Manjinivt́ ko (Microorganisms) Domain ren maraṅ Hitat́ ge.

column1: Typically a few micrometres in length, bacteria were among the first life forms to appear on Earth, and are present in most of its habitats.
column2: Jitiliṅ do typically chiminaṅ ge micrometer hoban Bacteria ko do, Ote chetan nel ean ayarùtar Life-form ko loḱkô lekaoḱa, anḍoḱ Ote ren sanam Habitat ko re menaḱkoa.

column1: Bacteria inhabit the air, soil, water, acidic hot springs, radioactive waste, and the deep biosphere of Earth's crust.
column2: Bacteria ko do, Hasa„ Daḱ„ Acidic Hot Spring„ Radioactive Waste„ Otecrust ren ikir Biosphere korekô taena.

column1: Bacteria play a vital role in many stages of the nutrient cycle by recycling nutrients and the fixation of nitrogen from the atmosphere.
column2: Nutrient ko recycle ê tan loḱ„ Atmosphere ren Nitrogen fix ê tan loḱ, Bacteria kodo Nutrient Cycle ren sange Stage kore Vital Role menaḱa.

column1: The nutrient cycle includes the decomposition of dead bodies; bacteria are responsible for the putrefaction stage in this process.
column2: Nutrient Cycle redo, Goćakanaḱ koaḱ Decomposition lekaoḱa; nen Process ren Putrefaction Stage do Bacteria ko tege hobana.

column1: In the biological communities surrounding hydrothermal vents and cold seeps, extremophile bacteria provide the nutrients needed to sustain life by converting dissolved compounds, such as hydrogen sulphide and methane, to energy.
column2: Hydrothermal Vent anḍoḱ Cold Seep kuṭi koren Biological Community kore do, Extremophile Bacteria ko, Hydrogen Sulphide„ Methane lekan leaṅ akan Compound ko Energy oḱge convert keet́ Life sustain re asitiṅ Nutrient kokô provide êa.

column1: Bacteria also live in mutualistic, commensal and parasitic relationships with plants and animals.
column2: Bacteria kodo, Sińjivt́ (Plants) anḍoḱ Senêjivt́ (Animals) ko loḱ mutualistic„ commensal„ parasitic Relationship reókô taena.

column1: Most bacteria have not been characterised and there are many species that cannot be grown in the laboratory.
column2: Most Bacteria ko do kakô characterise chaba akana, anḍoḱ Laboratory re kako sange ichi (grow) daeoḱ lekan Hita (Species) koó menaḱa.

column1: The study of bacteria is known as bacteriology, a branch of microbiology.
column2: Bacteria ko reaḱ Study do, Microbiology ren miat́ koto Bacteriology menoḱa.

column1: Like all animals, humans carry vast numbers (approximately 1013 to 1014) of bacteria.
column2: Sanam Senêjivt́ ko leka ge, hoo ko reó sange rená ge (approximately 1013 to 1014) Bacteria ko taena.

column1: Most are in the gut, though there are many on the skin.
column2: Sange do Úr re menaḱkô reó, láḱpaa do Láć Poṭa reko taena.

column1: Most of the bacteria in and on the body are harmless or rendered so by the protective effects of the immune system, and many are beneficial, particularly the ones in the gut.
column2: Homoo cheten„ bitar ren láḱpaa Bacteria dokô harmless gea, káakô reó ge, Immune System aḱ protective Effect tekô enka akana, sange dokô beneficial gea, particularly Láć Poṭa ren ko.

column1: However, several species of bacteria are pathogenic and cause infectious diseases, including cholera, syphilis, anthrax, leprosy, tuberculosis, tetanus and bubonic plague.
column2: Enkareóge, several Bacteriahita dokô pathogenic gea, anḍoḱ enko te Cholera„ Syphilis„ Anthrax„ Tunḍubanḍia„ Tuberculosis„ Tetanus„ Bubonic Plague ko lekan Chaálrua (Infectious Diseases) ko ooḱla.

column1: The most common fatal bacterial diseases are respiratory infections.
column2: Most common goóć Bacteriarua (Bacterial Diseases) kodo Saet́hora Chaálrua (Respiratory Infections) ko.

column1: Antibiotics are used to treat bacterial infections and are also used in farming, making antibiotic resistance a growing problem.
column2: Bacteria Ruachal (Bacterial Infection) buúgin re agujoṅoḱ Antibiotics kodo, Farming reó agujoṅoḱ te Antibiotic Resistance miat́ Growing Problem akana.

column1: Bacteria are important in sewage treatment and the breakdown of oil spills, the production of cheese and yogurt through fermentation, the recovery of gold, palladium, copper and other metals in the mining sector (biomining, bioleaching), as well as in biotechnology, and the manufacture of antibiotics and other chemicals.
column2: Bacteria ko do, Sewage Treatment anḍoḱ Nur Sunum breakdown re„ Unuput́process te Cheese anḍoḱ Yogurt baái re„ Mining Sector re Samaom„ Palladium„ Copper anḍoḱ eṭaḱ Metal ko recovery re, Biotechnology re, anḍoḱ Antibiotics„ eṭaḱ Chemical ko baái reko important gea.

column1: Once regarded as plants constituting the class Schizomycetes (“fission fungi”), bacteria are now classified as prokaryotes.
column2: Ayar kodo, Schizomycetes (“fission fungi”) Class ren Sińhita mente menoḱ taeken Bacteria ko do nahḱ Prokaryote mentekô classify akana.

column1: Unlike cells of animals and other eukaryotes, bacterial cells do not contain a nucleus and rarely harbour membrane-bound organelles.
column2: Senêjivt́„ eṭaḱ Eukaryote ko aete sapaniṅoḱge, Bacteria koaḱ Jivt́okoa redo, Okoamea (Nucleus) ká taena, anḍoḱ Membrane-bound Organelle ko do rarely ge harbour akanoḱa.

column1: Although the term bacteria traditionally included all prokaryotes, the scientific classification changed after the discovery in the 1990s that prokaryotes consist of two very different groups of organisms that evolved from an ancient common ancestor.
column2: Bacteria, nen Term re traditionally do sanam Prokaryote ko agumesaoḱ taeken reó ge, Prokaryote kore miat́ ge Ancient Common Ancestor aete haratersa akan barea esu rená tannga Organism Group menaḱ mente 1990 kore urum ean tayom, Scientific Classification ol ruaa eana.

column1: These evolutionary domains are called Bacteria and Archaea.
column2: Nen evolutionary Domain kin ge Bacteria anḍoḱ Archaea menoḱa.

column1: The word bacteria is the plural of the Neo-Latin bacterium, which is the Latinisation of the Ancient Greek βακτήριον (baktḗrion), the diminutive of βακτηρία (baktēría), meaning “staff, cane”, because the first ones to be discovered were rod-shaped.
column2: Ayarùtar urum nam len ko do jaṭagen (rod-shaped) kô taeken te, Ancient Greek re meaning do “Soṭa, Danḍaḱ” hobaoḱ βακτηρία (baktēría) aḱ Dimunitive βακτήριον (baktḗrion) aḱ Laátinêa (Latinisation) tana Nama-Latin (Neo-Latin) “Bacterium”, ena reaḱ plural ge “Bacteria” do.

column1: The ancestors of bacteria were unicellular microorganisms that were the first forms of life to appear on Earth, about 4 billion years ago.
column2: Bacteria koaḱ Ancestor ko do, 4 Billion sirma maaṅ Ote chetan ooḱl ean ayarùtar Jivt́form (Life form) tan Unicellular Manjivt́aḱ (Microorganism) ko.

column1: For about 3 billion years, most organisms were microscopic, and bacteria and archaea were the dominant forms of life.
column2: 3 Billion Serma noḱ lagit́, láḱpaa Jivt́aḱ (Organism) ko do man-man gekô taekena, Bacteria anḍoḱ Archaea ge dominant Jivt́form do.

column1: Although bacterial fossils exist, such as stromatolites, their lack of distinctive morphology prevents them from being used to examine the history of bacterial evolution, or to date the time of origin of a particular bacterial species.
column2: Stromatolite lekan Bacteria Fossil ko menaḱ reó, ena kore Distinctive Morphology banoḱ te, ena ko Bacteria Haratenersa (Evolution) examine re anḍoḱ particular Bacteriahita reaḱ Origin Time usanam (date) re ká agujoṅ daeoḱa.

column1: However, gene sequences can be used to reconstruct the bacterial phylogeny, and these studies indicate that bacteria diverged first from the archaeal/eukaryotic lineage.
column2: Enkareóge, Bacteria koaḱ Phylogeny reconstruct ê lagit́ Gene Sequence agujoṅ daeoḱa, nen Study kote do, Bacteria kodo ayar Archaea/Eukaryote Lineage aetekô chaṅ sangin eana mente inguloḱa.

column1: The most recent common ancestor (MRCA) of bacteria and archaea was probably a hyperthermophile that lived about 2.5 billion–3.2 billion years ago.
column2: Bacteria„ Archaea koaḱ Most Recent Common Ancestor (MRCA) do probably 2.5 Billion–3.2 Billion Serma noḱ maaṅ re taeken hyperthermophile.

column1: The earliest life on land may have been bacteria some 3.22 billion years ago.
column2: Hasaòte ren ayarùtar Jinivt́ do, 3.22 Billion Serma noḱ maaṅ re taeken Bacteria koge toraṅ.

column1: Bacteria are ubiquitous, living in every possible habitat on the planet including soil, underwater, deep in Earth's crust and even such extreme environments as acidic hot springs and radioactive waste.
column2: Bacteria ko dokô ubiquitous gea, Hasa„ Daḱsuba„ Otechuṭiàṭal (Earth's crust) ikir ko mesakeet́ sanam tae daáe lekan habitat re menaḱkôa, Acidic Hot Spring anḍoḱ Radioactive Waste lekan Extreme Environment ko reó ge.

column1: There are thought to be approximately 2×1030 bacteria on Earth, forming a biomass that is only exceeded by plants.
column2: Siń ko sekar láḱ parom akaat́ Biomass baái nen Bacteria ko, Ote chetan approximately 2×1030 menaḱkôa mente leka bai akana.

column1: They are abundant in lakes and oceans, in arctic ice, and geothermal springs where they provide the nutrients needed to sustain life by converting dissolved compounds, such as hydrogen sulphide and methane, to energy.
column2: Enko do, Lake re„ Ocean re„ Arctic Ice re anḍoḱ enko te Hydrogen Sulphide„ Methane lekan leaṅ akan Compound ko energy oḱ te Jinivt́ sustain oḱ Geothermal Spring ko rekô abundant gea.

column1: They live on and in plants and animals.
column2: Enko do Sińjivt́„ Senêjivt́ ko chetan„ bitar ko taena.

column1: Most do not cause diseases, are beneficial to their environments, and are essential for life.
column2: Enko láḱpaa ko tedo Ruahasu kaa ooḱla, tako Environment lagit́kô beneficial gea, oḍok Jinivt́ lagit́kô essential gea.

column1: The soil is a rich source of bacteria and a few grams contain around a thousand million of them.
column2: Hasa do rich Bacteria Nampai (Source) tana, chiminaṅ gram rege Thousand Million lekakô taena.

column1: They are all essential to soil ecology, breaking down toxic waste and recycling nutrients.
column2: Enko do, Toxic Waste raa rasum (break down) ê loḱ, Nutrient ko recycle ê loḱ, Hasa Ecology rekô essential gea.

column1: They are even found in the atmosphere and one cubic metre of air holds around one hundred million bacterial cells.
column2: Enko do, Hoyopai (Atmosphere) reó menaḱkôa, mit́ cubic metre Hoyo re mit́ Hundred Million leka Bacteria Jivt́okoa ko taena.

column1: The oceans and seas harbour around 3 x 1026 bacteria which provide up to 50% of the oxygen humans breathe.
column2: Ocean„ Sea kore, hoo ko saet́ê 50% Oxygen eém tan 3 x 1026 leka Bacteria ko taena.

column1: Only around 2% of bacterial species have been fully studied.
column2: Bacteriahita kore 2% noḱ leka sumat́ gekô study pura akana.

column1: Bacteria display a wide diversity of shapes and sizes.
column2: Bacteria koaḱ do shape„ size re wide diversity menaḱa.

column1: Bacterial cells are about one-tenth the size of eukaryotic cells and are typically 0.5–5.0 micrometres in length.
column2: Bacteria Jiwt́okoa koaḱ Size do, Eukaryote Jivt́okoa koaḱ one-tenth gea, anḍoḱ typically do 0.5–5.0 Micrometre jiliṅa.

column1: However, a few species are visible to the unaided eye—for example, Thiomargarita namibiensis is up to half a millimetre long, Epulopiscium fishelsoni reaches 0.7 mm, and Thiomargarita magnifica can reach even 2 cm in length, which is 50 times larger than other known bacteria.
column2: Enkareóge, chiminaṅ Bacteriahita ko do sama met́ te ko nel daeoḱa—Example do, tara-Millimetre jiliṅ Thiomargarita namibiensis„ 0.7 mm beṭaê Epulopiscium fishelsoni, urum akan eṭaḱ Bacteria ko aete 50 sa maraṅ 2 cm jaket́ beṭaê Thiomargarita magnifica.

column1: Among the smallest bacteria are members of the genus Mycoplasma, which measure only 0.3 micrometres, as small as the largest viruses.
column2: Huḍiń utar mente lekaoḱ Bacteria kore do, maraṅ utar Virus ko imin huḍiń 0.3 Micrometres ge jiliṅ Mycoplasma Genus renko.

column1: Some bacteria may be even smaller, but these ultramicrobacteria are not well-studied.
column2: Chiminaṅ Bacteria do anḍoḱkô huḍiṅa toraṅ, nen Uputarmanbacteria (Ultramicrobacteria) kodo bugi te kakô study akana.

column1: Most bacterial species are either spherical, called cocci (singular coccus, from Greek kókkos, grain, seed), or rod-shaped, called bacilli (sing. bacillus, from Latin baculus, stick).
column2: Láḱpaa Bacteriahita dokô ḍumaṅ (spherical) gea, cocci kô menoḱa (singular do coccus, Greek reaḱ kókkos, Gele, Hitajaṅ aete), baredokô Rod-shape gea, bacilli kô menoḱa (singular do bacillus, Latin reaḱ baculus, Jaṭa aete).

column1: Some bacteria, called vibrio, are shaped like slightly curved rods or comma-shaped; others can be spiral-shaped, called spirilla, or tightly coiled, called spirochaetes.
column2: Vibrio menoḱ chiminaṅ Bacteria do, jokoć lego akan Jaṭa baredo Comma lekaakô; eṭaḱ ko do Spirilla menoḱ Chunur-shape rekôa, anḍoḱ chiminaṅ Spirochaetes menoḱkô do uruć gekô binḍa akana.

column1: A small number of other unusual shapes have been described, such as star-shaped bacteria.
column2: Chimin noḱ leka do Star-shape Bacteria lekan eṭaḱ unusual Shape renkô ó ko describe akana.

column1: This wide variety of shapes is determined by the bacterial cell wall and cytoskeleton and is important because it can influence the ability of bacteria to acquire nutrients, attach to surfaces, swim through liquids and escape predators.
column2: Shape ko reaḱ wide Variety do Bacteria Okoaginil (Cell Wall)„ Cytoskelton te determine oḱa, anḍoḱ nena do Bacteria ko Nutrient naám re, Surface kore juaḱenn lagit́, Liíngiaḱ (Liquid) kore oyarenn, Predator ko taḱaete nirduḱnn Danae influence oḱa.

column1: Most bacterial species exist as single cells; others associate in characteristic patterns: Neisseria forms diploids (pairs), streptococci form chains, and staphylococci group together in “bunch of grapes” clusters.
column2: Láḱpaa Bacteriahita do Single Cell lekakô taena; eṭaḱ ko do Characteristic Pattern ko rekô jumurena: Neisseria do Diploid (Jimki) kô baina, Streptococci do Sinkii kô baina, anḍoḱ Staphylococci do “Ićtayar Rumpa” lekakô hunḍina.

column1: Bacteria can also group to form larger multicellular structures, such as the elongated filaments of Actinomycetota species, the aggregates of Myxobacteria species, and the complex hyphae of Streptomyces species.
column2: Bacteria do Actinomycetota Hita koaḱ jiliṅ Filament, Myxobacteria Hita koaḱ Aggregate, anḍoḱ Streptomyces Hita koaḱ Complex Hyphae leka láḱ maraṅ Multicellular Structure ókô bai daea.

column1: These multicellular structures are often only seen in certain conditions.
column2: Nen Multicellular Structure ko do often chelekan Condition rege nel namoḱa.

column1: For example, when starved of amino acids, myxobacteria detect surrounding cells in a process known as quorum sensing, migrate towards each other, and aggregate to form fruiting bodies up to 500 micrometres long and containing approximately 100,000 bacterial cells.
column2: Example lekate, Amino Acid kô ringa tan re, Myxobacteria do Quorum Sensing menoḱ Process te daradari ren Jivt́okoa kokô chirgalkoa, japaḱ tekô sen idina, anḍoḱ 500 micrometer jiliṅ, approximately 100,000 Bacteria Jivt́okoa lekaoḱ Fruiting Body bain gekô hunḍina.

column1: In these fruiting bodies, the bacteria perform separate tasks; for example, about one in ten cells migrate to the top of a fruiting body and differentiate into a specialised dormant state called a myxospore, which is more resistant to drying and other adverse environmental conditions.
column2: Nen Fruiting Body re, Bacteria do eṭaḱ-eṭaḱ Paeṭi rekô achuna; Example lekate, gelea re miat́ Jivt́okoa do Fruiting Body Chuṭi tekô sen atomena, anḍoḱ roohoḱ„ eṭaḱ Adverse Environmental Condition ko láḱ sahtiṅ dae lekan Myxospore menoḱ Specialised Dormant State kô bai tanngana.

column1: Bacteria, often lactic acid bacteria, such as Lactobacillus species and Lactococcus species, in combination with yeasts and moulds, have been used for thousands of years in the preparation of fermented foods, such as cheese, pickles, soy sauce, sauerkraut, vinegar, wine, and yogurt.
column2: Uúput́jaṅ (Yeast)„ Gumajaṅ (Mould) ko loḱte, Toagoólcharićjaṅhita (Lactobacillus species) anḍoḱ Toaḍúljaṅhita (Lactococcus species) kodo, Cheese„ Pickle„ Soy Sauce„ Sauerkraut„ Vinegar„ Wine„ Yogurt lekan Uput́jomaḱ bai re Thousand Thousand Serma agujoṅ hućoḱ akana.

column1: The ability of bacteria to degrade a variety of organic compounds is remarkable and has been used in waste processing and bioremediation.
column2: Dirisunum (Petroleum) ren Hydrocarbon ko digest dae lekan Bacteria ko do often Nur Sunum aákit́ rekô agujoṅoḱa.

column1: Fertiliser was added to some of the beaches in Prince William Sound in an attempt to promote the growth of these naturally occurring bacteria after the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill.
column2: 1989 ren Exxon Valdez Sunumnur tayom, Prince William Sound ren chiminaṅ Kuṭigitil kore nelekan naturally namoḱ Bacteria ko sangeoḱka mente Fertiliser kô em let́ taekena.

column1: These efforts were effective on beaches that were not too thickly covered in oil.
column2: Sunum te ibil rená gedo kaa bil suba len Kuṭigitil kore do nena Paeṭić em ket́ taekena.

column1: Bacteria are also used for the bioremediation of industrial toxic wastes.
column2: Bacteria kodo, Industrial Toxic Waste Bioremediation reókô agujoṅoḱa.

column1: In the chemical industry, bacteria are most important in the production of enantiomerically pure chemicals for use as pharmaceuticals or agrichemicals.
column2: Chemical Industry re, Pharmaceutical„ Agrichemical lekate agujoṅoḱ Enantiomerically Pure Chemical ko baái re Bacteria kokô important gea.

column1: Bacteria can also be used in place of pesticides in biological pest control.
column2: Bacteria kodo Biological Pest Control re Pesticide ko satikô agujoṅ daeoḱa.

column1: This commonly involves Bacillus thuringiensis (also called BT), a Gram-positive, soil-dwelling bacterium.
column2: Nena re commonly do, BT ókô meta Hasa re taen Gram-positive Bacteria, Bacillus thuringiensis agujoṅoḱa.

column1: Subspecies of this bacteria are used as Lepidopteran-specific insecticides under trade names such as Dipel and Thuricide.
column2: Nen Bacteria ren Subhita do Dipel„ Thuricide lekan Trade Name te Lepidopteran-specific Insecticide lekakô agujoṅoḱa.

column1: Because of their specificity, these pesticides are regarded as environmentally friendly, with little or no effect on humans, wildlife, pollinators, and most other beneficial insects.
column2: Nen Pesticide ko do hoo ko„ Birjivt́„ Pollinator„ eṭaḱ Beneficial Chidu ko re Effect do jokoć ge baredo banoḱ te, akoaḱ Specificity lagit́, Environmentally Friendly kô menoḱa.

column1: Because of their ability to quickly grow and the relative ease with which they can be manipulated, bacteria are the workhorses for the fields of molecular biology, genetics, and biochemistry.
column2: Akoaḱ ã́cha sangenn Danae anḍoḱ manipulate kô daeoḱ Relative Lanavar te, Bacteria do Molecular Biology, Genetics anḍoḱ Biochemistry Pii ren Arãaùrić.

column1: By making mutations in bacterial DNA and examining the resulting phenotypes, scientists can determine the function of genes, enzymes, and metabolic pathways in bacteria, then apply this knowledge to more complex organisms.
column2: Bacteria DNA re mutation keet́ result namoḱ Phenotype ko examine keet́, Scientist ko Bacteria koaḱ Gene„ Enzyme„ Metabolic Pathway reaḱ Function kokô determine daea, tayom nen Sẽa ge láḱ complex Jivt́aḱ ko re apply oḱa.

column1: This aim of understanding the biochemistry of a cell reaches its most complex expression in the synthesis of huge amounts of enzyme kinetic and gene expression data into mathematical models of entire organisms.
column2: Miat́ Jivt́okoa reaḱ Biochemistry urum bodeê teaḱ Aim do, sange-sange Enzyme Kinetic„ Gene Expression Data kin synthesis keet́ goṭa Jivt́aḱ reaḱ Mathematical Model ko baái re complex utar leka express oḱa.

column1: This is achievable in some well-studied bacteria, with models of Escherichia coli metabolism now being produced and tested.
column2: Nena do chiminaṅ Well-studied Bacteria re achieve daeoḱa, anḍoḱ Escherichia coli reaḱ Metabolism Model do nahḱ bai ooḱl tana anḍoḱ test oḱ tana.

column1: This understanding of bacterial metabolism and genetics allows the use of biotechnology to bioengineer bacteria for the production of therapeutic proteins, such as insulin, growth factors, or antibodies.
column2: Bacteria koaḱ Metabolism onḍoḱ genetics reaḱ nelekan Urumsẽa te, Biotechnology horate Bacteria ko Insulin„ Growth Factor baredo Antibody lekan Therapeutic Protein ko baái lagit́kô bioengineer daeoḱa.

column1: Because of their importance for research in general, samples of bacterial strains are isolated and preserved in Biological Resource Centers.
column2: General Reasearch re akoaḱ Importance menaḱ te, Bacteria Stain reaḱ Sample ko do Biological Resource Centre ko re isolate anḍoḱ preserve akana.

column1: This ensures the availability of the strain to scientists worldwide.
column2: Neka te goṭa Otesae ren Scientist ko lagit́ en Strain available rika daeoḱa.

column1: Bacteria were first observed by the Dutch microscopist Antonie van Leeuwenhoek in 1676, using a single-lens microscope of his own design.
column2: Bacteria do ayarùtar 1676 re Dutch Microscopist Antonie van Leeuwenhoek aćge design let́ Single-lens Nelmansanaṕ tekô nel lena.

column1: He then published his observations in a series of letters to the Royal Society of London.
column2: Entayom aćaḱ Observation ko do Royal Society of London taḱ te kul let́ Letter Series horateć publish ket́a.

column1: Bacteria were Leeuwenhoek's most remarkable microscopic discovery.
column2: Leeuwenhoek aḱ Most Remarkable Discovery do Bacteria ge.

column1: Their size was just at the limit of what his simple lenses could resolve, and, in one of the most striking hiatuses in the history of science, no one else would see them again for over a century.
column2: Enkoaḱ Size do aćaḱ Lens ko resolve dae taeken Limit rená re taekena, anḍoḱ do, Science reaḱ History ren most striking Hiatus oḱge, mit́ Century aete láḱ leka jahć ó enko kakô nel uraa ket́koa.

column1: His observations also included protozoans which he called animalcules, and his findings were looked at again in the light of the more recent findings of cell theory.
column2: Aćaḱ Observation re ać Animalcules eć nutum let́ Protozoan ko ókô taekena, aćaḱ Finding ko do láḱ recent teaḱ Cell Theory marsal te nel uraa eana.

column1: Christian Gottfried Ehrenberg introduced the word “bacterium” in 1828.
column2: 1828 re Christian Gottfried Ehrenberg “Bacterium” Kajihon eć introduce ket́a.

column1: In fact, his Bacterium was a genus that contained non-spore-forming rod-shaped bacteria, as opposed to Bacillus, a genus of spore-forming rod-shaped bacteria defined by Ehrenberg in 1835.
column2: In fact, aćaḱ Bacterium do non-spore forming Rod-shaped Bacteria ko mesa ken Genus ge, 1835 re Ehrenberg define let́ Baccilus menoḱ spore-forming Rod-shaped Bacteria aete tannga.

column1: Louis Pasteur demonstrated in 1859 that the growth of microorganisms causes the fermentation process and that this growth is not due to spontaneous generation (yeasts and molds, commonly associated with fermentation, are not bacteria, but rather fungi).
column2: Manjivt́ koaḱ Growth tege Unuput́process do hobana, anḍoḱ nen Growth do Spontaneous Generation te do ká hobana (Commonly do Unuput́ loḱ kajimesaoḱ Unuput́jaṅ anḍoḱ Guúmajaṅ do Bacteria káa, Fungi) -mente 1859 re Louis Pasteur demonstrate ket́a.

column1: Along with his contemporary Robert Koch, Pasteur was an early advocate of the germ theory of disease.
column2: Aćaḱ Contemporary Robert Koch loḱ, Pasteur do Ruahasu reaḱ Germ Theory ren early Advocate eć taekena.

column1: Before them, Ignaz Semmelweis and Joseph Lister had realised the importance of sanitised hands in medical work.
column2: Akin ayar, Ignaz Sammelweis anḍoḱ Joseph Lister do Medical Paeṭi re Tí Sanitisation reaḱ Importance kin chirgal let́ taekena.

column1: Semmelweis, who in the 1840s formulated his rules for handwashing in the hospital, prior to the advent of germ theory, attributed disease to “decomposing animal organic matter”.
column2: 1840 kore Raánpai re Tí abuṅenn teaḱ Rule ko formulate ken Semmelweis do Germ Theory hućoḱ ayar, Ruahasu do “decompose oḱ tan Animal Organic Matter” te hobanać men let́a.

column1: His ideas were rejected and his book on the topic condemned by the medical community.
column2: Medical Community taḱ aćaḱ Idea ko reject eana, anḍoḱ nen Topic re aćaḱ Sapagom ko condemn eana.

column1: After Lister, however, doctors started sanitising their hands in the 1870s.
column2: Lister tayom mendo, 1870 kore Doctor ko tako Tíkô sanitise eṭeć ket́a.

column1: A feral child (also called wild child) is a young individual who has lived isolated from human contact from a very young age, with little or no experience of human care, social behavior, or language.
column2: Birbagehon (wild child ókô metaà) do, Baleḱtaesirma aete ge Hoojanapaḱ (human contact) sangin re tannga akan aete, Hooneélsapaṕ (human care)„ sangitala Sepentapae (social behaviour)„ Jagar reaḱ Nelàdasẽa (experience), menaḱ re jokoć ge baredo banoḱ lekan baleḱ Individual.

column1: Such children lack the basics of primary and secondary socialization.
column2: Enkan Hon ko taḱ Primary„ Secondary Socialization reaḱ Reht́sẽa (basic knowledge) kaa taena.

column1: The term is used to refer to children who have suffered severe abuse or trauma before being abandoned or running away.
column2: Nen term do, Egerrupú (abuse) baredo Trauma te tensuba len tayom bage eṛaḱ ean baredo nir at́ ean Hon ko iíngul re agujoṅoḱa.

column1: They are sometimes the subjects of folklore and legends, often portrayed as having been raised by animals.
column2: Enko ge misa misa kodo Folklore„ Legend ko ren Subject akanakô, often do, Birjivt́ ko hara maraṅ ken gekô portray akana.

column1: While there are many cases of children being found in proximity to wild animals, there are no eyewitness accounts of animals feeding human children.
column2: Birjivt́ ko japaḱ re Hon ko nam akan sange case ko menaḱ reó, Birjivt́ ko Hon kokô asulkô tan reaḱ Nenelmet́kanatai (eyewitness account) ko banoḱa.

column1: Feral children lack the basic social skills that are normally learned in the process of enculturation.
column2: Birbagehon ko taḱ, normally do Enculturation Process te etooḱ basic Sangetalaaḱepeto (social skill) kaa taena.

column1: For example, they may be unable to learn to use a toilet, have trouble learning to walk upright after walking on all fours their whole lives, or display a complete lack of interest in the human activity around them.
column2: For example, enko Aṕenpaisenjonoṅ (toilet usage) kakô eto dae emana„ goṭa Taesirma otetí akan te ombaḱ sen keet́ Mulitingusen kakô etooḱ emana„ aka daradari ren Hoosepentipí (human activity) paa te Nelònorbaánoḱkô uduṕ emanêa.

column1: They often seem mentally impaired and have almost insurmountable trouble learning a human language.
column2: Enko often Hataṅimpair akan ge ko neloḱa, anḍoḱ, Hoojanagar (human language) eton re káparomdaeoḱ noḱ trouble taena.

column1: The impaired ability to learn a natural language after having been isolated for so many years is often attributed to the existence of a critical period for language learning, and taken as evidence in favor of the critical period hypothesis.
column2: Esu sirma tannga sangin len taeken te, Naturaljagar Etondanae impair janaḱ lagit́ do, often Jagarèneto reaḱ critical period menaḱ menteaḱ ge Reason menoḱa, anḍoḱ ena ge Critical Period Hypothesis lagit́aḱ Evidence lekate uduḱ joṅoḱa.

column1: There is little scientific knowledge about feral children.
column2: Birbagehon ko reaḱ Scientificsẽa do esu beteć ge menaḱa.

column1: One of the best-documented cases has supposedly been that of sisters Amala and Kamala, described by Reverend J A L Singh in 1926 as having been “raised by wolves” in a forest in India.
column2: Kajioḱ lekate, best-documented Case kore miat́ do, India aḱ Bir re “Ṭẽoḱ ko asul kena” mente 1926 re Reverend J A L Singh kaji sartal ken Amala„ Kamala Unḍiboko kin.

column1: French surgeon Serge Aroles, however, has persuasively argued that the case was a fraud, perpetrated by Singh in order to raise money for his orphanage.
column2: France ren Surgeon Serge Aroles mendo, en case do, Singh taćaḱ Orphanage lagit́ Funding harom aágu lagit́ uskur let́ Fraud mente persuasively ć argue akat́a.

column1: Child psychologist Bruno Bettelheim states that Amala and Kamala were born mentally and physically disabled.
column2: Amala„ Kamala do hataṅhomoo disable akan gekin unduṕ lena mente Honkopsychologist Bruno Bettelheim kaji akat́a.

column1: Yet other scientific studies of feral children exist, such as the case of Genie.
column2: Enreóge, Genie aḱ case lekan Birbagehon ko chetan eṭaḱ Scientific Study ko menaḱ gea.

column1: Prior to the 1600s, feral and wild children stories were usually limited to myths and legends.
column2: 1600 ko maaṅ do, Birbagehon koaḱ Story ko do usually Myth„ Legend ko jóṅ ge taekena.

column1: In those tales, the depiction of feral children included hunting for food, running on all fours instead of two, and not knowing language.
column2: En story ko re Birbagehon koaḱ Depiction re, Jom nam te sangar tanaḱ, bar Kaṭa te ká otetí akan te nir tanaḱ, Jagar ká etoannaḱ ko taemesa kena.

column1: Philosophers and scientists were interested in the concept of such children, and began to question if these children were part of a different species from the human family.
column2: Philosopher„ Scientist ko, enkan Hon ko menaḱ teaḱ Concept paa te Nelònor taekena, enkan Hon ko do Hoohita aete eṭaḱ Hita ren ko chi mentekô kuli eṭeć let́ taekena.

column1: The question was taken seriously as science tried to name and categorize the development of humans, and the understanding of the natural world in the 18th and 19th century.
column2: 18th„ 19th century re Science re Hooharamanaraṅ (human development) nutumê anḍoḱ haṭińòkoaê (categorize) teaḱ„ Natural World munḍiê teaḱ attempt taeken loḱ, nen Kunuli do seriously ataṅ ean taekena.

column1: Around the 20th century, psychologists were attempting to differentiate between biological behavior and culture.
column2: 20th century naaćpaa, Psychologist ko Biological Behaviour anḍoḱ Culture urumsapaniṅê teaḱkô attempt let́a.

column1: Feral children who lived in isolation or with animals provided examples of this dilemma.
column2: Tapannga re baredo Birjivt́ ko loḱ taeken Birbagehon ko en Dilemma ren Example lekakô taekena.

column1: Journalistic accounts of children raised by animals.
column2: Birjivt́ ko taḱ hara len Hon ko reaḱ Journal Kanatai ko.

column1: Marina Chapman claimed to have lived with weeper capuchin monkeys in the Colombian jungle from the age of five to about nine, following a botched kidnapping in about 1954.
column2: Marina Chapman do 'huḍiṅ akan 5 sirma aete 9 sirma noḱ jooṅ do fail ean Anarkit́ tayom Columbia aḱ Bir re Weeper Capuchin Gai ko loḱń taekena' menteć claim akat́a.

column1: Unusual for feral children, she went on to marry, have children and live a largely normal life with no persisting problems.
column2: Birbagehon ko re nena ko do unusual gea, mendo ać tayom koć Aandi eana„ Hon ko hoba eana„ persisting Problem ko banoḱ loḱ aćaḱ Life largely normal ge taekena.

column1: Robert Mayanja (1982) lost his parents in the Ugandan Civil War at the age of three, when Milton Obote's soldiers raided their village, around 50 miles (80 km) from Kampala.
column2: Robert Mayanja (1982), 3 sirma akan re Uganda ren Civil War imita, Milton Obote aḱ Soldier ko Kampala aete 80 km saniṅ tać Hatu ko raid ket́ re, Engaàpu kineć at́ ket́kina.

column1: Robert then survived in the wild, presumably with vervet monkeys, for three years until he was found by soldiers of National Resistance Army.
column2: Robert do National Resistance Army ren Soldier ko nam let́ić jóṅ apea sirma Bir reć jivt́ lena, presumably Vervet Gai ko loḱ.

column1: Saturday Mthiyane (or Mifune) (1987), a boy of around five, was found after spending about a year in the company of monkeys in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa.
column2: Saturday Mthiyane (Mifune menê reó) (1987), 5 sirma lekać hobaoḱ lekan Koahon do, South Africa ren KwaZulu-Natal re mit́ sirma Gai ko loḱ taekeneet́eć nam lena.

column1: He was given the name Saturday after the day he was found, and Mthiyane was the name of the headmistress of the Special School which took him in.
column2: Ać nam len Musiṅ re, Saturday kô saki ket́ića, oḍoḱ Mythiyane do ać admission ken Special School ren Headmistress aḱ Nutum taekena.

column1: At the age of around 17, he could still not talk, and still walked and jumped like a monkey.
column2: 17 sirma hoba len re, jagar kać dae taeken gea, Gai leka geć sen„ ućenn taekena.

column1: He never ate cooked food and refused to share or play with other children.
column2: Isin akan Jomaḱ musiṅ ó kać jom ket́a, anḍoḱ eṭaḱ Hon ko loḱ Hapaṭiń„ Inuṅ kaćaḱ eana.

column1: In 2005 he was killed in a fire.
column2: 2005 re, Sengel teć ló goć eana.

column1: John Ssebunya, from Uganda, was a toddler when his father killed his mother and hanged himself.
column2: Uganda ren John Ssebunya do, Apute, Engateć goć ket́ić tayomeć haka goćen ean re, Oómbaḱhoneć taekena.

column1: Instead of going into a care facility, he went to live with vervet monkeys.
column2: Care Facility te senoḱ sati, Vervet Gai ko loḱ taeneć senoḱ eana.

column1: For two years he learned how to forage and travel.
column2: Bar sirma, Forage„ Travel eć eto kena.

column1: The monkeys protected him in the wild.
column2: Bir re Gai ko raka let́ića.

column1: When he was around seven years old, he was brought back to civilization.
column2: 7 sirma lekać hoba len re, Civilization teć agu ruaa lena.

column1: According to a local villager, when he was a child, the only forms of communication he was capable of were crying and demanding food, and he was a “wild boy” whom everyone feared.
column2: Miat́ Enpaihaturenićaḱ Kaji lekate, ać Hon len re, ać dae taeken Communication form do Raḱ„ Jomaḱ asi sekar, anḍoḱ ać do saben ko boroać lekan “Bir ren hon” geć taekena.

column1: He has since gained full speech abilities and has also twice competed in the Special Olympics for Uganda.
column2: Imita aete ać do tayom, full Jagardanaeć eto ket́a, anḍoḱ Uganda lagit́ bar dao Special Olympics reóć compete let́a.

column1: Hessian wolf-children:â€Š15â€“7â€Š (1304, 1341 and 1344) lived with the Eurasian wolf in the forests of Hesse:.
column2: Hesse ren Ṭẽoḱ Hon ko do (1304, 1341 oḍoḱ 1344), Hesse ren Bir ko re Eurasian Ṭẽoḱ loḱkô taekena:.

column1: The first boy (1304) was taken by wolves at age 3 and found when 7 or 8 by Benedictine monks, the wolves having cared for him by “surrounding him in cold weather, and fed him the best meat from the hunt.”
column2: Ayaraḱ Koahon do (1304), 3 sirmać hoba akan re Ṭẽoḱ ko goḱ ket́ića, 7, 8 sirma lekać hoba len re, Ṭẽoḱ ko “Rabaṅ re abarum tala ket́ić te, sangar agu let́ buginùtar Jilu ajom ket́ić” tekô nelić taeken re Benedictine monk ko nam let́ića.

column1: He was later sent to the court of Prince Henry, and became accustomed to human society but said he preferred the wolves.
column2: Enić tayom do Prince Henry aḱ Court teć kul eana, anḍoḱ Human Society ć nel sebe ean reó 'Ṭẽoḱ ko taḱ geń sukuat́ać' men.

column1: The second boy (1341) resisted capture, biting and scratching; he continued to run on all four limbs and hid under a bench.
column2: Second Koahon do (1341), ká saṕ ichinneć nam kena, huaḱ gotaḱ kenać, otetí akan te geć nir baa kena anḍoḱ Bench suba reć ukunn eana.

column1: He refused any food given to him and died shortly after being found.
column2: Aćkô emat́ Jomaḱ ko kaćaḱ eana anḍoḱ nam len tayom ge chimin singi aurioḱ regeć goć eana.

column1: The third boy (1344) was found in the winter near the farm Echtzel in Wetterau.
column2: Third Koahon (1344) do, Rabaṅdipili Witterau ren farm Echtzel japaḱ reć nam lena.

column1: He had lived with wolves in a dense wooded area known as “the Hart” for 12 years.
column2: The Hart kô meta ibil Bir menaḱ Area re Ṭẽoḱ ko loḱ 12 sirmać taekena.

column1: He was found by nobles who used the area as hunting grounds.
column2: En area do Hunting Ground leka let́ Noble ko nam let́ića.

column1: He eventually lived to the age of 80, but has also been reported as having died shortly after discovery.
column2: Eventually 80 sirmaoḱ geć tae kena, nam ean tayom geć goć eana mente ó Report menaḱa mendo.

column1: The critical period hypothesis is a theory within the field of linguistics and second language acquisition that claims a person can only achieve native-like fluency in a language before a certain age.
column2: Critical Period Hypothesis do, jaać ge reó, miat́ language eton re, native-lekan fluency do certain age auri beṭaê regeć achieve daea menten, Linguistics„ Second Language Acquisition field ren miat́ hypothesis tana.

column1: It is the subject of a long-standing debate in linguistics and language acquisition over the extent to which the ability to acquire language is biologically linked to developmental stages of the brain.
column2: Linguistics„ Language Acquisition re, Language Eton Daṉaê do okon Extent jooṅ Hataṅ Haramaraṅ Stage ko loḱ Biological Link menaḱa menteaḱ long-standing debate re, nena miat́ Subject akana.

column1: The critical period hypothesis was first proposed by Montreal neurologist Wilder Penfield and co-author Lamar Roberts in their 1959 book Speech and Brain Mechanisms, and was popularized by Eric Lenneberg in 1967 with Biological Foundations of Language.
column2: Critical Period Hypothesis do ayarùtar 1959 re akinaḱ Sapagom “Speech and Brain Mechanisms” re Montreal ren neurologist Wilder Penfield„ co-author Lamar Roberts tekin propose let́a, oḍoḱ 1967 ren “Biological Foundations of Language” loḱ Eric Lenneberg popular ket́a.

column1: The critical period hypothesis states that the first few years of life is the crucial time in which an individual can acquire a first language if presented with adequate stimuli, and that first-language acquisition relies on neuroplasticity of the brain.
column2: Critical Period Hypothesis re, eneoṕaḱ chiminaṅ taesirma do crucial gea, lali stimuli emoḱ redo, jaać reó ge First Language kô eto daea mente ó, First Language Eneto do, Hataṅ Neuroplasticity dae suba rea mente ó menoḱa.

column1: If language input does not occur until after this time, the individual will never achieve a full command of language.
column2: Language Emànader nen Period tayom enaṅ hoban redo, enić Language reaḱ full command jaa musiṅ ó kać achieve renáêa.

column1: There is much debate over the timing of the critical period with respect to second-language acquisition (SLA), with estimates ranging between 2 and 13 years of age.
column2: Estimate ko 2 aete 13 sirma jooṅ senoḱ tan loḱ, Second Language Eneto reaḱ Critical Period reaḱ Timing chetan ó esu debate menaḱa.

column1: The critical period hypothesis is derived from the concept of a critical period in the biological sciences, which refers to a set period in which an organism must acquire a skill or ability, or said organism will not be able to acquire it later in life.
column2: Critical Period Hypothesis do, jahn Organism reó, miat́ Set Period loḱ jahn Skill„ Danaeć eton te hobana, baredo tayomaḱ Taesirma ko kać eto daea menten Biological Sciences ren Critical Period Concept aete derive akana.

column1: The Dunning–Kruger effect is a cognitive bias in which people with limited competence in a particular domain overestimate their abilities.
column2: Dunning-Kruger effect do, miat́ particular domain re limited competence menaḱ tan hoo ko, takoaḱ Ability kô overestimate ê teaḱ miat́ Cognitive Bias.

column1: It was first described by David Dunning and Justin Kruger in 1999.
column2: Ena ayar utar 1999 re Justin Kruger anḍoḱ David Dunning tekin describe let́ taekena.

column1: Some researchers also include the opposite effect for high performers: their tendency to underestimate their skills.
column2: Chiminaṅ Researcher ko do, high performer kore ena reaḱ opposite effect (skill underestimate enn teaḱ tendency) ókô include êa.

column1: Numerous similar studies have been done.
column2: Esu sangi similar study ko hoba akana.

column1: The Dunning–Kruger effect is usually measured by comparing self-assessment with objective performance.
column2: Dunning–Kruger effect do usually, self-assessment anḍoḱ objective performance umaa keet́ measure oḱa.

column1: For example, participants may take a quiz and estimate their performance afterward, which is then compared to their actual results.
column2: For example, participant ko miat́ Quiz re duṕ eaneet́ takô performance kô estimate êa, ena ge tayom takoaḱ actual result loḱ umaaoḱa.

column1: The original study focused on logical reasoning, grammar, and social skills.
column2: Original study re do logical reasoning„ grammar„ social skill chetan re focus taekena.

column1: There is disagreement about the causes of the Dunning–Kruger effect.
column2: Dunning–Kruger effect reaḱ cause chenaḱ tana menteaḱ re disagreement menaḱa.

column1: According to the metacognitive explanation, poor performers misjudge their abilities because they fail to recognize the qualitative difference between their performances and the performances of others.
column2: Metacognitive explanation lekate, poor performer ko, takoaḱ performance oḍoḱ eṭaḱ koaḱ performance tala ren qualitative sapaniṅ kakô urum dae te, takoaḱ ability kô misjudge êa.

column1: Eugenics (/juːˈdʒɛnɪks/ yoo-JEN-iks; from Ancient Greek εύ̃ (eû) 'good, well' and -γενής (genḗs) 'come into being, growing') is a set of beliefs and practices that aim to improve the genetic quality of a human population.
column2: Eugenics (yoo-JEN-iks; Ancient Greek ren εύ̃ (eû) 'bugi, good, well', anḍoḱ -γενής (genḗs) 'unduboḱ, haraoḱ aete bai akana) do human population re genetic quality improve oḱ kâ menten belief anḍoḱ practice kokô metaà.

column1: Historically, eugenicists have attempted to alter human gene pools by excluding people and groups judged to be inferior or promoting those judged to be superior.
column2: History re, eugenicist ko do inferior mente nel ean ko exclude keet́, anḍoḱ superior mente nel ean ko promote keed human gene pool alter ê teaḱ ko attempt leda.

column1: In recent years, the term has seen a revival in bioethical discussions on the usage of new technologies such as CRISPR and genetic screening, with heated debate around whether these technologies should be considered eugenics or not.
column2: Daaradaḱ sirma ko re do, nen term do CRISPR anḍoḱ genetic screening lekan nama technology reaḱ usage reaḱ bioethical discussion ko re agu ruaa akana, nekan technology ko do Eugenics mene re bugia chi kaa mente heated debate hoban tan gea.

column1: The principles of eugenics have been in practice since ancient Greece.
column2: Eugenics reaḱ principle ko do ancient Greece period aete ge practice re menaḱa.

column1: Plato suggested applying the principles of selective breeding to humans around 400 BCE.
column2: Human ko re selective breeding principle apply ê teaḱ do 400 BCE naaćnoḱ re Plato suggest led taekena.

column1: Early advocates of eugenics in the 19th century regarded it as a way of improving groups of people.
column2: 19th century ren early Eugenicsadvocate ko, ena do Peoplegroup ko improve ê Hora lekakô nelê taekena.

column1: In contemporary usage, the term eugenics is closely associated with scientific racism.
column2: Contemporary usage re, Eugenics nen term do, scientific racism loḱ closely associate oḱa.

column1: Modern bioethicists who advocate new eugenics characterize it as a way of enhancing individual traits, regardless of group membership.
column2: New Eugenics advocate ê tan Modern bioethicist ko do, ena regardless of group membership, individual aḱ Trait ko enhance ê tan Hora lekakô characterize êa.

column1: The contemporary history of eugenics began in the late 19th century, when a popular eugenics movement emerged in the United Kingdom, and then spread to many countries, including the United States, Canada, Australia, and most European countries (e.g., Sweden and Germany).
column2: Eugenics reaḱ Contemporary history do, 19th century aḱ United Kingdom re popular Eugenics movement unduṕ janeet́ United States„ Canada„ Australia„ goṭa noḱ European country (e.g., Sweden„ Germany) ko re nitir ean loḱ eṭeć eana.

column1: In this period, people from across the political spectrum espoused eugenic ideas.
column2: Nen period re, across political spectrum ren ko saben eugenic idea ko espouse let́ taekena.

column1: Consequently, many countries adopted eugenic policies, intended to improve the quality of their populations' genetic stock.
column2: Consequently, esu country ko re, akoaḱ Population Genetic Stock improve ê Intention loḱ Eugenic Policy ko adopt eana.

column1: Such programs included both positive measures, such as encouraging individuals deemed particularly “fit” to reproduce, and negative measures, such as marriage prohibitions and forced sterilization of people deemed unfit for reproduction.
column2: Enkan program ko re, reproduction lagit́ particularly “fit” ge nel ean ko encourage ko lekan positive measure ko ó taekena anḍoḱ reproduction lagit́ unfit ge nel ean koaḱ forced sterilisation„ marriage prohibition ó taekena.

column1: Those deemed “unfit to reproduce” often included people with mental or physical disabilities, people who scored in the low ranges on different IQ tests, criminals and “sexual and social deviants”, and members of disfavored minority groups.
column2: Reproduction lagit́ unfit ge nel ean ko re, often do mental„ physical disability menaḱ ko ó, epeṭaḱ IQ test ko re low range re score ket́ ko ó, criminal ko„ “sexual„ social deviant ko” ó„ disfavor akan minority group ko ókô taekena.

column1: The eugenics movement became associated with Nazi Germany and the Holocaust when the defense of many of the defendants at the Nuremberg trials of 1945 to 1946 attempted to justify their human-rights abuses by claiming there was little difference between the Nazi eugenics programs and the US eugenics programs.
column2: 1945 aete 1946 reaḱ Nuremberg trial kore, sapangi defendant koaḱ defense ko do, Nazi koaḱ Eugenics program re anḍoḱ US aḱ Eugenics program re beteḱ ge sapaniṅ menaḱ mente argue keet́ akoaḱ human rights abuse ko justify ê teaḱkô attempt let́ te, Eugenics movement do Nazi Germany oḍoḱ Holocaust loḱ associate eana.

column1: In the decades following World War II, with more emphasis on human rights, many countries began to abandon eugenics policies, although some Western countries (the United States, Canada, and Sweden among them) continued to carry out forced sterilizations.[citation needed]
column2: World War II tayomaḱ decade ko re, chiminaṅ Western country kore (enare United States„ Canada„ Sweden kore) forced sterilisation kô continue let́ taekena ge reó, human rights re láḱ emphasis em ean loḱ, sapangi Disum kore Eugenics policy dokô bage eṭeć ket́a.

column1: A criticism of eugenics policies is that, regardless of whether negative or positive policies are used, they are susceptible to abuse because the genetic selection criteria are determined by whichever group has political power at the time.
column2: Eugenics reaḱ negative„ positive bar policy re jahn miat́ salae reó ena do, genetic selection criteria enìmitaṅ political power menaḱ group ge determine ê te, abuse oḱ lagit́ susceptible ge taena mente Eugenics policies reaḱ criticism menaḱa.

column1: Furthermore, many criticize negative eugenics in particular as a violation of basic human rights, seen since 1968's Proclamation of Tehran, as including the right to reproduce.
column2: Furthermore, 1968 aḱ Tehran Proclamation tayom, basic human rights re reproduction reaḱ right ó menaḱ gea mente nel ean te, sangê hoo ko negative Eugenics do ena reaḱ violation tana mentekô criticise ket́a.

column1: Another criticism is that eugenics policies eventually lead to a loss of genetic diversity, thereby resulting in inbreeding depression due to a loss of genetic variation.
column2: Eugenics policy kote do, eventually genetic diversity at́oḱa, entayom genetic variation at́oḱ te inbreeding depression beṭaoḱa mente ena reaḱ anḍoḱ miat́ Criticism menaḱa.

column1: India, officially the Republic of India (ISO: Bhārat Gaṇarājya), is a country in South Asia.
column2: India, official nutum Republic of India (Bhārat Gaṇarājya), do South Asia reaḱ miat́ disum tana.

column1: It is the seventh-largest country by area; the most populous country as of June 2023; and from the time of its independence in 1947, the world's most populous democracy.
column2: June 2023 jooṅ re nena do Area lekate 7 aḱ maraṅ disum; anḍoḱ saben ko aete láḱ population an disum tana; anḍoḱ 1947 sirma re independence aete nena do world reaḱ saben aete láḱ population an democracy tana.

column1: Bounded by the Indian Ocean on the south, the Arabian Sea on the southwest, and the Bay of Bengal on the southeast, it shares land borders with Pakistan to the west; China, Nepal, and Bhutan to the north; and Bangladesh and Myanmar to the east.
column2: South re Indian Ocean, southwest re Arabian Sea, southeast re Bay of Bengal menaḱa. West re Pakistan, North paa China, Nepal anḍoḱ Bhutan, east paa Bangladesh anḍoḱ Myanmar loḱ chirmit́ menaḱa. Indian Ocean ren Sri Lanka, Maldives naeć re menaḱa.

column1: In the Indian Ocean, India is in the vicinity of Sri Lanka and the Maldives; its Andaman and Nicobar Islands share a maritime border with Thailand, Myanmar, and Indonesia.
column2: India aḱ Andaman Nicobar Island koaḱ do Thailand, Myanmar, Indonesia loḱ maritime Chirmit́ menaḱa.

column1: Modern humans arrived on the Indian subcontinent from Africa no later than 55,000 years ago.
column2: Modern human ko do Africa aete Indian subcontinent te tapayomutar 55,000 sirma maaṅ rekô hućoḱ lena.

column1: Their long occupation, initially in varying forms of isolation as hunter-gatherers, has made the region highly diverse, second only to Africa in human genetic diversity.
column2: Eoṕ re hunter-gatherer ko leka varying form of isolation re taen taen te enkoaḱ sipirmaoḱgen Banasa te nen Region esu diverse eana, human-genetic-diversity lekate ma Africa sekar láḱ eana.

column1: Settled life emerged on the subcontinent in the western margins of the Indus river basin 9,000 years ago, evolving gradually into the Indus Valley Civilisation of the third millennium BCE.
column2: 9,000 sirma maaṅ Sindhu Gaḍa Basin western Kuṭi re settled-life nelnam eana, ena ge tayom mae-mae te 3000 BCE re Indus Valley Civilization baioḱge evolve eana.

column2: Gautama Buddha aḱ teaching chetan bit́ akan Buddhism paa te, middle-class bage keet́ saben social-class ren ko or idi len taekena; Buddha aḱ life reaḱ chronicling do India aḱ recorded-history reaḱ eneoṕ re central Role taekena.

column1: In an age of increasing urban wealth, both religions held up renunciation as an ideal, and both established long-lasting monastic traditions.
column2: Urban wealth saaroḱ tan time Period re, nen barea religion re renunciation ge ideal mente rikâ lena, anḍoḱ en barea rege long-lasting monastic Tradition establish eana.

column1: Politically, by the 3rd century BCE, the kingdom of Magadha had annexed or reduced other states to emerge as the Mauryan Empire.
column2: Politics nele redo, 300 BCE loḱ do, Magadha kingdom ge eṭaḱ state ko annex keet́ baredo reduce keet́ Mauryan Empire bai eana.

column1: The empire was once thought to have controlled most of the subcontinent except the far south, but its core regions are now thought to have been separated by large autonomous areas.
column2: Nen empire aḱ do far South bage keet́ goṭa noḱ subcontinent re control taekena mente menoḱ taekena, mendo nahḱ menoḱ tana, core Region ko do maparaṅ autonomous Area ko te tannga lena mente.

column1: The Mauryan kings are known as much for their empire-building and determined management of public life as for Ashoka's renunciation of militarism and far-flung advocacy of the Buddhist dhamma.
column2: Mauryan king ko Ashoka aḱ militarism banage anḍoḱ Buddha aḱ dhamma reaḱ osar-saniṅ advocacy lagit́ chimin ko nutumana, imin ge nutum empire-building anḍoḱ public Life reaḱ determined Management lagit́ ó menaḱa.

column1: The Sangam literature of the Tamil language reveals that, between 200 BCE and 200 CE, the southern peninsula was ruled by the Cheras, the Cholas, and the Pandyas, dynasties that traded extensively with the Roman Empire and with West and Southeast Asia.
column2: 200 BCE anḍoḱ 200 CE tala re, southern-peninsula do, Roman Empire anḍoḱ West anḍoḱ Southeast Asia loḱ extensive-trade taeken Chera ko, Chola ko, anḍoḱ Pandya dynasty ko rule let́ taekena mente Tamil language reaḱ Sangam literature re uduboḱ tana.

column1: In North India, Hinduism asserted patriarchal control within the family, leading to increased subordination of women.
column2: North India re, Hinduism iate family re Patriarchal Control agu tala ean te, êra koaḱ subordination láḱ eana.

column1: By the 4th and 5th centuries, the Gupta Empire had created a complex system of administration and taxation in the greater Ganges Plain; this system became a model for later Indian kingdoms.
column2: 4th anḍoḱ 5th century loḱ do, Gupta Empire iate greater Ganga gaṛa Plain re administration anḍoḱ taxation reaḱ Complex System bai ean taekena; nen system ge tayomaḱ Indian kingdom ko lagit́ model bai eana.

column1: Under the Guptas, a renewed Hinduism based on devotion, rather than the management of ritual, began to assert itself.
column2: Critical Period Hypothesis re, eneoṕaḱ chiminaṅ taesirma do crucial gea, lali stimuli emoḱ redo, jaać reó ge First Language kô eto daea mente ó, First Language Eneto do, Hataṅ Neuroplasticity dae suba rea mente ó menoḱa.

column1: This renewal was reflected in a flowering of sculpture and architecture, which found patrons among an urban elite.
column2: Nen Namasanaṕ do urban Elite ko patronize let́ sculpture anḍoḱ architecture re reflect eana.

column1: Classical Sanskrit literature flowered as well, and Indian science, astronomy, medicine, and mathematics made significant advances.
column2: Classical Sanskrit Literature ó hara sagen eana, India ren Science, Astronomy, Medicine, anḍoḱ Mathematics ko significantly advance eana.

column1: The Indian early medieval age, from 600 to 1200 CE, is defined by regional kingdoms and cultural diversity.
column2: 600 aete 1200 CE, India aḱ Early Medieval Age do, regional kingdom ko anḍoḱ cultural diversity te nutum len taekena.

column1: When Harsha of Kannauj, who ruled much of the Indo-Gangetic Plain from 606 to 647 CE, attempted to expand southwards, he was defeated by the Chalukya ruler of the Deccan.
column2: 606 aete 647 CE re Indo-Gangetic Plain goṭa naeć rule ken Kannauj ren Harsha south paa teć expand lekead re, Deccan ren Chalukya ruler taḱaeteć haratiṅ eana.

column1: When his successor attempted to expand eastwards, he was defeated by the Pala king of Bengal.
column2: Aćaḱ successor east paa teć expand lekead re Bengal ren Pala king taḱaeteć haratiṅ eana.

column1: When the Chalukyas attempted to expand southwards, they were defeated by the Pallavas from farther south, who in turn were opposed by the Pandyas and the Cholas from still farther south.
column2: Chalukya ko south paa teko expand lekead re anḍoḱ saniṅ south ren Pallava ko taḱaeteko haratiṅ eana, anḍoḱ neko ó anḍoḱ láḱ saniṅ south ren Pandya anḍoḱ Chola ko darom kedkoa.

column1: No ruler of this period was able to create an empire and consistently control lands much beyond their core region.
column2: Nen period ren jaan ruler ko ó empire bai keet́ akoaḱ core Region aete láḱ ote consistantly kakô control daeada.

column1: During this time, pastoral peoples, whose land had been cleared to make way for the growing agricultural economy, were accommodated within caste society, as were new non-traditional ruling classes.
column2: Nen time-period re, non-traditional ruling class ko leka ge, growing agricultural economy lagit́ hora bai re ote amiṅ ean pastoral people ko ó caste society reko accommodate eana.

column1: The caste system consequently began to show regional differences.
column2: Enate, caste society re regional difference ko nelnam eana.

column1: In the 6th and 7th centuries, the first devotional hymns were created in the Tamil language.
column2: 6th anḍoḱ 7th century re, Tamil language ren ayarutar devotional-hymn ko bai eana.

column1: They were imitated all over India and led to both the resurgence of Hinduism and the development of all modern languages of the subcontinent.
column2: Ena ko goṭa India re imitate eana anḍoḱ enate Hinduism ó resurge eana anḍoḱ subcontinent ren saben modern language ko ó develop eana.

column1: Indian royalty, big and small, and the temples they patronised drew citizens in great numbers to the capital cities, which became economic hubs as well.
column2: India aḱ huṛiṅ maraṅ saben lekan royalty koaḱ iate, anḍoḱ ako patronise let́ temple ko iate, economic hub leka ó bai ean capital city ko te esu sangi citizen ko or idi eana.

column1: Temple towns of various sizes began to appear everywhere as India underwent another urbanisation.
column2: India re anḍoḱ misa hoban tan urbanisation loḱ epeṭaḱ size ren temple town ko saben muli nelnam eana.

column1: By the 8th and 9th centuries, the effects were felt in Southeast Asia, as South Indian culture and political systems were exported to lands that became part of modern-day Myanmar, Thailand, Laos, Brunei, Cambodia, Vietnam, Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia.
column2: 8th anḍoḱ 9th century loḱ do, South India reaḱ culture anḍoḱ political sysem ko tisiṅaḱ Myanmar, Thailand, Laos, Brunei, Cambodia, Vietnam, Philippines, Malaysia anḍoḱ Indonesia re mesa ean disum ko te export ean loḱ te ena ko reaḱ epelaṅ Southeast Asia re nel eana.

column1: Indian merchants, scholars, and sometimes armies were involved in this transmission; Southeast Asians took the initiative as well, with many sojourning in Indian seminaries and translating Buddhist and Hindu texts into their languages.
column2: Nen transmission re Indian merchant, scholar, misâ ko do army koaḱ role taekena; ena re Indian seminary ko re basa keet́ Buddhist anḍoḱ Hindu text ko akoaḱ language te translate ê loḱ Southeast Asia ren koaḱ initiative ó taeken gea.

column1: After the 10th century, Muslim Central Asian nomadic clans, using swift-horse cavalry and raising vast armies united by ethnicity and religion, repeatedly overran South Asia's north-western plains, leading eventually to the establishment of the Islamic Delhi Sultanate in 1206.
column2: 10th century tayom, ãacha-sadom cavalry anḍoḱ ethnicity religion te tolmit́ (unite) akan army ko te Central Asia ren nomadic Muslim clan ko, dao ge dao South Asia aḱ north-western plain ko attack yet́ taekena, ena ko te ge tayom 1206 re Islamic Delhi Sultanate establish eana.

column1: The sultanate was to control much of North India and to make many forays into South India.
column2: En Sultanate te ge goṭa noḱ North India control lena, anḍoḱ ena te ge South India chetan te sangi dao attack hoba lena.

column1: Although at first disruptive for the Indian elites, the sultanate largely left its vast non-Muslim subject population to its own laws and customs.
column2: Although at first disruptive for the Indian elites, the sultanate largely left its vast non-Muslim subject population to its own laws and customs.

column1: By repeatedly repulsing Mongol raiders in the 13th century, the sultanate saved India from the devastation visited on West and Central Asia, setting the scene for centuries of migration of fleeing soldiers, learned men, mystics, traders, artists, and artisans from that region into the subcontinent, thereby creating a syncretic Indo-Islamic culture in the north.
column2: 13th century re nen sultanate iate, dao ge dao Mongol raider ko darom kôl ean te, India save eana West anḍoḱ Central Asia re hoba ean devastation aete, nena ko te ge tayom en Region aete nir tan soldier, scholar, mystic, trader, artist, artisan ko chiminaṅ century subcontinent te ko migrate hućoḱ teaḱ hora bai eana, enate ge north re syncretic Indo-Islamic culture bai eana.

column1: The sultanate's raiding and weakening of the regional kingdoms of South India paved the way for the indigenous Vijayanagara Empire.
column2: Sultanate aḱ raid ko te, anḍoḱ weak oḱ tan South India ren regional kingdom ko te indigenous Vijayanagara Empire aḱ hora bai eana.

column1: Embracing a strong Shaivite tradition and building upon the military technology of the sultanate, the empire came to control much of peninsular India, and was to influence South Indian society for long afterwards.
column2: Strong Shaivite tradition otoṅê loḱ, anḍoḱ sultanate aḱ military technology aete bai rakabê loḱ nen empire te goṭa noḱ peninsular India control eana, anḍoḱ tayom do sipirmaoḱ ge South India ren society influence eana.

column1: In the early 16th century, northern India, then under mainly Muslim rulers, fell again to the superior mobility and firepower of a new generation of Central Asian warriors.
column2: Eteoṕaḱ 16th century re mainly Muslim ruler ko suba re taeken northern India, anḍoḱ misâ superior mobility anḍoḱ firepower an Central Asian warrior koaḱ nama generation taḱaete haratiṅ eana.

column1: The resulting Mughal Empire did not stamp out the local societies it came to rule.
column2: Enaaḱ result te bai ean Mughal Empire re, rule suba ean local society ko ẽeć do kakô ẽeć muchat́ eana.

column1: Instead, it balanced and pacified them through new administrative practices and diverse and inclusive ruling elites, leading to more systematic, centralised, and uniform rule.
column2: Ensati, akô do nama administrative practice ko te anḍoḱ diverse, inclusive ruling elite koaḱ iatekô balance anḍoḱ pacify ean taekena.

column1: Eschewing tribal bonds and Islamic identity, especially under Akbar, the Mughals united their far-flung realms through loyalty, expressed through a Persianised culture, to an emperor who had near-divine status.
column2: Mughal ko, especially Akbar suba re, tribal bond anḍoḱ Islamic identity bage keet́, Persianised culture te near-divine status menaḱ tan emperor chetan re em len loyalty te, akoaḱ osar saniṅ ote chirmit́ ko unite ket́a.

column1: The Mughal state's economic policies, deriving most revenues from agriculture and mandating that taxes be paid in the well-regulated silver currency, caused peasants and artisans to enter larger markets.
column2: Laaḱpaa revenue do agriculture aete hućoḱ tan, anḍoḱ tax do well-regulated silver-currency te emoḱ ka mente mandate taeken Mughal state aḱ economic policy iate peasant anḍoḱ artisan ko larger market tekô bolo eana.

column1: The relative peace maintained by the empire during much of the 17th century was a factor in India's economic expansion, resulting in greater patronage of painting, literary forms, textiles, and architecture.
column2: Goŧa noḱ 17th century re empire maintain let́ relative-peace do India aḱ economic expansion ren miat́ factor leka taekena, enate painting, literary form, textile, anḍoḱ architecture ko láḱ patronage em eana.

column1: Newly coherent social groups in northern and western India, such as the Marathas, the Rajputs, and the Sikhs, gained military and governing ambitions during Mughal rule, which, through collaboration or adversity, gave them both recognition and military experience.
column2: Mughal rule imita, North anḍoḱ West India re Maratha, Rajput anḍoḱ Sikh lekan namage coherent akan social group ko re, military anḍoḱ governing ambition nelnam eana, ena te ge akô do collaboration te ó adversity te ó recognition anḍoḱ military experience ko nam akit́ ket́a.

column1: Expanding commerce during Mughal rule gave rise to new Indian commercial and political elites along the coasts of southern and eastern India.
column2: Mughal rule imita expand oḱ tan commerce te South anḍoḱ East India coast re nama commercial anḍoḱ political elite ko nelnam eana.

column1: As the empire disintegrated, many among these elites were able to seek and control their own affairs.
column2: Empire disintegrate oḱ tan loḱ, nen elite ko re ge sangi do ako akoaḱ affair ako tekô control dae taekena.

column1: By the early 18th century, with the lines between commercial and political dominance being increasingly blurred, a number of European trading companies, including the English East India Company, had established coastal outposts.
column2: 18th century eteoṕ loḱ do, commercial anḍoḱ political dominance tala ren panaa gaar ẽeć tersaoḱ tan loḱ, English East India Company mesa keet́aḱ Europe aḱ sangi trading company ko patukam kuṭi (coastal) outpost kokô establish sekaa let́ taekena.

column1: The East India Company's control of the seas, greater resources, and more advanced military training and technology led it to increasingly assert its military strength and caused it to become attractive to a portion of the Indian elite; these factors were crucial in allowing the company to gain control over the Bengal region by 1765 and sideline the other European companies.
column2: Mughal ko, especially Akbar suba re, tribal bond anḍoḱ Islamic identity bage keet́, Persianised culture te near-divine status menaḱ tan emperor chetan re em len loyalty te, akoaḱ osar saniṅ ote chirmit́ ko unite ket́a.

column1: Its further access to the riches of Bengal and the subsequent increased strength and size of its army enabled it to annex or subdue most of India by the 1820s.
column2: Bengal aḱ biti reaḱ anḍoḱ láḱ access, anḍoḱ en tayomaḱ peeć anḍoḱ army size re lanahḱ te láḱpaa India annex baredo subdue ć dae eana.

column1: India was then no longer exporting manufactured goods as it long had, but was instead supplying the British Empire with raw materials.
column2: India aete anḍoḱ do sêdae re sipirmaoḱ ge taeken leka manufactured good ko do kaa export oḱ taekena, ena sati, British ko raw material ko supply oḱ taekena.

column1: Many historians consider this to be the onset of India's colonial period.
column2: Sangi historian ko do nena ge India aḱ colonial period ren anaṅ mentekô metaà.

column1: By this time, with its economic power severely curtailed by the British parliament and having effectively been made an arm of British administration, the East India Company began more consciously to enter non-economic arenas, including education, social reform, and culture.
column2: Nen imita loḱ do, British parliament iate akôaḱ economic power curtail ean ko te anḍoḱ sari samanaṅ re do British administration aḱ miat́ tí bai ean ko te, East India Company ren ko adaan aete ge education, social reform, culture mesa keet́aḱ non-economic Area rekô bolo eana.

column1: Historians consider India's modern age to have begun sometime between 1848 and 1885.
column2: Historian koaḱ menatiṅ lekate India reaḱ modern-age do 1848 anḍoḱ 1885 tala paa re eoṕ lena.

column1: The appointment in 1848 of Lord Dalhousie as Governor General of the East India Company set the stage for changes essential to a modern state.
column2: 1848 re Lord Dalhousie East India Company ren Governor General lekać appoint ean teaḱ te ge miat́ modern state baái ren essential change ko lagit́ stage bai eana.

column1: These included the consolidation and demarcation of sovereignty, the surveillance of the population, and the education of citizens.
column2: Ena ko re sovereignty reaḱ consolidation anḍoḱ demarcation, hoo koaḱ surveillance anḍoḱ citizen koaḱ education ó mesa akana.

column1: Technological changes—among them, railways, canals, and the telegraph—were introduced not long after their introduction in Europe.
column2: Europe re introduce len aete te láḱ Sipirma aurioḱ re ge—railway, ur loor (canal) anḍoḱ Telegraph emanaḱ—technological change ko introduce lena.

column1: However, disaffection with the company also grew during this time and set off the Indian Rebellion of 1857.
column2: Mendo, nen time period re ge company lagit́ dissafection ó láḱ lena anḍoḱ ena te 1857 ren Indian Rebellion uskur eana.

column1: Fed by diverse resentments and perceptions, including invasive British-style social reforms, harsh land taxes, and summary treatment of some rich landowners and princes, the rebellion rocked many regions of northern and central India and shook the foundations of Company rule.
column2: Invasive gen British-style social reform, harsh land tax, chiminaṅ landowner anḍoḱ prince ko summary ge treat ket́ ko teaḱ ko mesa keet́aḱ diverse resentment anḍoḱ perception te ajom hara len nen rebellion te do northern anḍoḱ central India ren sangi Region ko ituṅ eana anḍoḱ Company rule ren foundation ekela eana.

column1: Although the rebellion was suppressed by 1858, it led to the dissolution of the East India Company and the direct administration of India by the British government.
column2: 1858 loḱ re nen rebellion suppress ean re ó, ena te mendo East India Company aḱ Leneyaṅ (dissolution) anḍoḱ British government hotete India aḱ direct administration agu eana.

column1: Proclaiming a unitary state and a gradual but limited British-style parliamentary system, the new rulers also protected princes and landed gentry as a feudal safeguard against future unrest.
column2: Unitary state anḍoḱ mãe mãe te limited British parliament system proclaim keet́, nen nama ruler ko prince anḍoḱ ote hasa an land gentry ko kapalomaḱ unrest aeten safeguard leka ko protect ledkôa.

column1: In the decades following, public life gradually emerged all over India, leading eventually to the founding of the Indian National Congress in 1885.
column2: Ena tayomaḱ decade ko re, India re public life mãe mãe te nelnam eana, anḍoḱ ena te ge 1885 re Indian National Congress bai bit́ eana.

column1: The rush of technology and the commercialisation of agriculture in the second half of the 19th century was marked by economic setbacks, and many small farmers became dependent on the whims of far-away markets.
column2: 19th century reaḱ second tara re technology anḍoḱ commercialisation reaḱ ãacha hunujuḱ do economic setback ko te marka lena, anḍoḱ sangi hupuṛiṅ farmer ko do sangin market reaḱ whim koaḱ dae suba eanakô.

column1: There was an increase in the number of large-scale famines, and, despite the risks of infrastructure development borne by Indian taxpayers, little industrial employment was generated for Indians.
column2: Maraṅ-scale ringâ ko reaḱ leneka láḱ eana, anḍoḱ do, infrastructure development reaḱ risk India ren taxpayer ko chetan re taeken re ó, India ren ko lagit́ esu kom industrial employment generate ean taekena.

column1: There were also salutary effects: commercial cropping, especially in the newly canalled Punjab, led to increased food production for internal consumption.
column2: Salutary effect ko ó taeken gea: especially do nama ge Canal ko bai akan Punjab re Commercial Cropping te, Internal Consumption lagit́ Food Production increase eana.

column1: The railway network provided critical famine relief, notably reduced the cost of moving goods, and helped nascent Indian-owned industry.
column2: Railway network te critical famine relief em eana, goods ko ipidi reaḱ cost adit́ eana, anḍoḱ namage unduṕ akan Indian-owned industry denga eana.

column1: After World War I, in which approximately one million Indians served, a new period began.
column2: Approximately mit́ million Indian ko serve ket́ ayaraḱ World War tayom, Nama Period eoṕ eana.

column1: It was marked by British reforms but also repressive legislation, by more strident Indian calls for self-rule, and by the beginnings of a nonviolent movement of non-co-operation, of which Mahatma Gandhi would become the leader and enduring symbol.
column2: Ena do British Reform kote urum len ge, repressive legislation te, India ren koaḱ Self Rule lagit́ ten anḍoḱ keṭeć Anasi te, Mahatma Gandhi do leader anḍoḱ enduring symbol eć bai ean Non-Cooperation ren Nonviolent Movement reaḱ Eneoṕ ko te ó ge.

column1: During the 1930s, slow legislative reform was enacted by the British; the Indian National Congress won victories in the resulting elections.
column2: 1930 ko re, British ko mãe mãe ten Legislative Reform ko enact ket́a; ena te hoba ean Election ko re Indian National Congress dae eana.

column1: The next decade was beset with crises: Indian participation in World War II, the Congress's final push for non-co-operation, and an upsurge of Muslim nationalism.
column2: En tayomaḱ 10 sirma do Crisis kote toḱ lena: World War II re India ren koaḱ Menesa, Non-Cooperation lagit́ Congress aḱ chapanaṕ unuskur, anḍoḱ Muslim Nationalism reaḱ pair Ranakaṕ.

column1: All were capped by the advent of independence in 1947, but tempered by the partition of India into two states: India and Pakistan.
column2: Saben ge 1947 re Independence reaḱ Hunujuḱ te koṭoṅ ean reó, India barea State, India„ Pakistan re haṭiń ean te temper ó temper eana.

column1: Vital to India's self-image as an independent nation was its constitution, completed in 1950, which put in place a secular and democratic republic.
column2: Independent nation lekate India aḱ self-image baioḱ lagit́ do, secular anḍoḱ democratic republic bit́ ken, 1950 re sekaa jan, India aḱ constitution aḱ vital role taekena.

column1: Per the London Declaration, India retained its membership of the Commonwealth, becoming the first republic within it.
column2: London declaration lekate, India ren ko commonwealth reaḱ membership kô retain ket́a, enka te ena ren ayarutar Member kô bai eana.

column1: Economic liberalisation, which began in the 1980s and the collaboration with Soviet Union for technical know-how, has created a large urban middle class, transformed India into one of the world's fastest-growing economies, and increased its geopolitical clout.
column2: 1980 ko re eoṕ len economic liberalisation te„ technical know-how lagit́ Soviet Union loḱaḱ collaboration te, miat́ large urban middle class bai hućoḱ eana„ India do Ote chetan ãachaùtar Growing Economic ko loḱ lekaoḱ ge transformer eana„ anḍoḱ India aḱ geopolitical Clout láḱ eana.

column1: Yet, India is also shaped by seemingly unyielding poverty, both rural and urban; by religious and caste-related violence; by Maoist-inspired Naxalite insurgencies; and by separatism in Jammu and Kashmir and in Northeast India.
column2: Enreó, India do, unyielding ge neloḱ rural„ urban ripinga te; religious„ caste-related Violence te; Maoist koaḱ te inspire akan Naxalite insurgency ko te; Jammu anḍoḱ Kashmir„ Northeast India ren separatism ko te ó shape akana.

column1: It has unresolved territorial disputes with China and with Pakistan.
column2: India aḱ China„ Pakistan loḱ kaa resolve akan ote chirmit́ dispute menaḱa.

column1: India's sustained democratic freedoms are unique among the world's newer nations; however, in spite of its recent economic successes, freedom from want for its disadvantaged population remains a goal yet to be achieved.
column2: India aḱ sustained democratic freedom do ote chetan ren nama noḱ disum ko group re unique gea; mendo, daaradaḱ economic success ko menaḱ sante, India ren disadvantage akan ko riningâ aete raa kô teaḱ goal do, sangin re menaḱ akat́ gea.

column1: India accounts for the bulk of the Indian subcontinent, lying atop the Indian tectonic plate, a part of the Indo-Australian Plate.
column2: Indo-Australian Plate aḱ miat́ part tan Indian-tectonic-plate chetan re menaḱ tan India do Indian subcontinent aḱ goṭa-noḱ-homoo (bulk) leka menaḱa.

column1: India's defining geological processes began 75 million years ago when the Indian Plate, then part of the southern supercontinent Gondwana, began a north-eastward drift caused by seafloor spreading to its south-west, and later, south and south-east.
column2: India aḱ defining geological process ko do, 75 million sirma maaṅ re, en imita southern supercontinent Gondawana aḱ part taeken Indian Plate, seafloor south-west paa te, anḍoḱ tayom ko do south„ south-east paa te udur aguoḱ tan te north-east paa te usa eoṕ ean re eoṕ lena.

column1: Simultaneously, the vast Tethyan oceanic crust, to its northeast, began to subduct under the Eurasian Plate.
column2: Ena ko hoban tan imita ge, India aḱ northeast ren maraṅ lekan Tethyan oceanic crust do Eurasian Plate latar re subduct eṭeḱ eana.

column1: These dual processes, driven by convection in the Earth's mantle, both created the Indian Ocean and caused the Indian continental crust eventually to under-thrust Eurasia and to uplift the Himalayas.
column2: Ote aḱ Convection te hoban taeken en barea process te, Indian Ocean ó bai eana, anḍoḱ Indian continental crust te tayom Eurasia under-thrust ean te Himalaya buru ó udur rakaṕ eana.

column1: Immediately south of the emerging Himalayas, plate movement created a vast crescent-shaped trough that rapidly filled with river-borne sediment and now constitutes the Indo-Gangetic Plain.
column2: Rakaboḱ tan Himalay buru japaḱ rená south re, plate movement te maraṅ lekan cresent-shaped bahni bai eana, tayom do ena ãacha ge gaṛa atu agu let́ Sediment te pereć eana, ena te ge nahḱaḱ Indo-Gangetic Plain bai akana.

column1: The original Indian plate makes its first appearance above the sediment in the ancient Aravalli range, which extends from the Delhi Ridge in a southwesterly direction.
column2: India aḱ original plate do, sediment chetan re ayarutar Delhi Ridge aete south-west paa te bil akan ancient Aravalli range re nel lena.

column1: To the west lies the Thar Desert, the eastern spread of which is checked by the Aravallis.
column2: West re do, eastern Binil Aravallis te koṭoṅ akan Thar Desert menaḱa.

column1: The Tungabhadra, with rocky outcrops, flows into the peninsular Krishna River.
column2: Rocky outcrops ann Tungabhadra do, peninsular Krishna Gaḍa re atu chabaoḱa.

column1: The remaining Indian Plate survives as peninsular India, the oldest and geologically most stable part of India.
column2: Sareć akan Indian Plate do, mariùtar„ geologically India aḱ most-stable-part part tan peninsular India leka menaḱ akat́a.

column1: It extends as far north as the Satpura and Vindhya ranges in central India.
column2: Ena ge sangin utar do north re Satpura jooṅ anḍoḱ central re Vindhya range jooṅ sartal akana.

column1: These parallel chains run from the Arabian Sea coast in Gujarat in the west to the coal-rich Chota Nagpur Plateau in Jharkhand in the east.
column2: Ena reaḱ parallel chain ko do west re Gujrat ren Arabian Sea coast aete, east ren Jharkhand aḱ coal-rich Chota Nagpur Plateau jooṅ bil akana.

column1: India's coastline measures 7,517 kilometres (4,700 mi) in length; of this distance, 5,423 kilometres (3,400 mi) belong to peninsular India and 2,094 kilometres (1,300 mi) to the Andaman, Nicobar, and Lakshadweep island chains.
column2: India aḱ coastline do 7,517 kilometer jiliṅa; nen distance reaḱ 5,423 kilometre do peninsular India rea, anḍoḱ 2,094 kilometer do Andaman„ Nicobar„ Lakshadweep island-chain rea.

column1: Major Himalayan-origin rivers that substantially flow through India include the Ganges and the Brahmaputra, both of which drain into the Bay of Bengal.
column2: Substantially India re atun major Himalayburusaṅ (Himalayan-origin) Gaḍa ko re Ganga„ Brahmaputra menaḱa, banar ge Bay of Bengal re atu chabaoḱa.

column1: Important tributaries of the Ganges include the Yamuna and the Kosi; the latter's extremely low gradient, caused by long-term silt deposition, leads to severe floods and course changes.
column2: Ganga gaṛaaḱ important Tributary ko re Yamuna„ Kosi ko lekaoḱa; sipirmaoḱge Tilat́ duṕ duṕ te hoba akan Kosi aḱ extremely-low-gradient te severe bán anḍoḱ gaṛa reaḱ Course change ko hobana.

column1: Major peninsular rivers, whose steeper gradients prevent their waters from flooding, include the Godavari, the Mahanadi, the Kaveri, and the Krishna, which also drain into the Bay of Bengal; and the Narmada and the Tapti, which drain into the Arabian Sea.
column2: Hić láḱan Gradient te daḱ kaa bánoḱ major peninsular Gaḍa ko re Bay of Bengal re atu chabaoḱ Godavari„ Mahanadi„ Kaveri„ Krishna ko; anḍoḱ Arabian Sea re atu chabaoḱ Narmada„ Tapti ko lekaoḱa.

column1: Coastal features include the marshy Rann of Kutch of western India and the alluvial Sundarbans delta of eastern India; the latter is shared with Bangladesh.
column2: Coastal Feature ko re, west India ren Rann of Kutch„ east India ren alluvial hasaann Sunderban Delta kin lekaoḱa; ena ren tayomanaḱ do Bangladesh loḱ haṭiṅ akana.

column1: India has two archipelagos: the Lakshadweep, coral atolls off India's south-western coast; and the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, a volcanic chain in the Andaman Sea.
column2: India re barea Archipelago menaḱa: India aḱ south-west Patukâm Kuṭi ren coral Atoll tan Lakshadweep; anḍoḱ Andaman Honpatukâm ren Sengelburu Chain Andaman Nicobar Island ko.

column1: Indian climate is strongly influenced by the Himalayas and the Thar Desert, both of which drive the economically and culturally pivotal summer and winter monsoons.
column2: India aḱ Climate do, economically„ culturally pivotal Situṅ„ Rabaṅdipiliaḱ Monsoon ko aágu tan Himalayburu anḍoḱ Thar Desert te strongly influence akana.

column1: The Himalayas prevent cold Central Asian katabatic winds from blowing in, keeping the bulk of the Indian subcontinent warmer than most locations at similar latitudes.
column2: Himalayburu menaḱ te, Central Asia ren Katabatic Hoyo ko koṭoṅoḱa; ena te, bulk of Indian Subcontinent do, ena loḱ mipit́noḱ Latitude ren Location ko aeteó urgumlaaḱ gea.

column1: The Thar Desert plays a crucial role in attracting the moisture-laden south-west summer monsoon winds that, between June and October, provide the majority of India's rainfall.
column2: June aete October tala re India aḱ láḱpaa Gamadaḱ eém tan daḱpereć south-west aḱ Situṅdipili Monsoon Hoyo ko or aágu re, Thar Desert aḱ Crucial Role menaḱa.

column1: Four major climatic groupings predominate in India: tropical wet, tropical dry, subtropical humid, and montane.
column2: India re predominantly upunea major Climatic Grouping menaḱa: Singichirmit́ Oda (Tropical Wet), Singichirmit́ Rooh (Tropical Dry), Singichirmit́suba Losom (Subtropical Humid), anḍoḱ Montane.

column1: According to the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the Indian economy in 2024 was nominally worth $3.94 trillion; it was the fifth-largest economy by market exchange rates and is, at around $15.0 trillion, the third-largest by purchasing power parity (PPP).
column2: International Monetary Fund (IMF) lekate, 2024 re India aḱ Economy reaḱ Nominal Value $3.94 Trillion taekena; nen Economy Market Exchange Rate lekate mṍeaḱ-maraṅa, anḍoḱ $15.0 Trillion naaćpaa beṭaê Purchasing Power Parity (PPP) lekate apéaḱ-maraṅa.

column1: With its average annual GDP growth rate of 5.8% over the past two decades, and reaching 6.1% during 2011–2012, India is one of the world's fastest-growing economies.
